awd_titl_txt: EAGER:  New lower-cost technology to produce many entangled photons and test their properties
awd_abstract_narration:
Title: New lower-cost technology to produce many entangled photons and test their properties

The new science of quantum entanglement has opened up a wide variety of new, emerging and possible technologies, such as quantum computing, secure quantum communication, quantum imaging, quantum lithography (an approach to nanofabrication) and others.  The cost of producing two entangled photons is a crucial driver in the development and use of these technologies. This PI has been one of the world leaders in producing high-precision entangled  photons. He (along with two other  groups) has also been able to produce three entangled photons.  He has had a recent breakthrough, proven in experiment, for producing two entangled photons by a radically new technology, which promises a great reduction in cost, and also opens the door to entangling more than two photons at an acceptable cost and precision. In this project, he plans to demonstrate that this promise is real, and to undertake new studies of fundamental physics made possible by the availability of more entangled photons. It is hoped that these new studies will open the door to new paradigms and technologies in quantum technology, based on the use of more than two entangled photons.

Past demonstrations of three entangled photons (in a large laboratory in Sichuan province of China) have relied on complicated systems using multiple steps of four-wave mixing in nonlinear crystals. This new technique uses thermal effects and noise cancellation to achieve the same effect.  In experiment, it accurately reproduces the usual two-photon Bell double coincidence rate. In the first stage of this work, the PI will produce the GHZ "phi" state, and perform the equivalent of the Bell's Theorem experiment but with three polarizers, and varying the order at which the polarizers are reached, as a test of fundamental principles. He will then progress to demonstrating larger and larger numbers of entangled photons, up to more than 100, and performing experiments relevant to possible applications.

por.por_cntn:
Qubits play an essential role in quantum processing, such as quantum computing and networking. Producing an n-qubit, especially when n>>2, is expensive and not easy. The objective of this project is to utilize a new lower-cost technology to entangle many photons into a Bell state (n = 2) and a Greenberger-Horne-Zeilinger (GHZ) state (n > 2), as well as an n-qubit. Also it is to study their properties and to compare with the two-photon or n-photon entangled states generated from other higher-cost processes such as the nonlinear optical process of Spontaneous Parametric Down-conversion (SPDC).

The working mechanism to entangle randomly grouped photons can be easily pictured from Einstein’s view of light. Recall, in 1905, Einstein introduced a granularity to radiation, abandoning the continuum interpretation of Maxwell. This led to a statistical view of light. In Einstein’s picture, a natural light source, such as the sun or a distant star, consists of a large number of point-like sub-sources (“atomic transitions” in modern language) and each emits its own subfield (“strahlenbündel” in German, translated to “bundle of ray” in English, or “photon” in modern language), in a random manner: the mth subfield (photon) that is created from the mth point-like sub-source (atomic transition) may propagate in all possible directions with all possible random phases. This kind of light has the popular name of “thermal light” or “thermal field.” The mean intensity of thermal light measured by a photodetector is the result of self-interference: a subfield (photon) interfering with the subfield (photon) itself. On the other hand, its intensity fluctuation is the result of a subfield (mth) interfering with a different subfield (nth, m ≠ n).  The intensity fluctuation is usually considered “noise” in the measurement of mean intensity. In fact, the “noise” may not be considered “noise” at all in the joint-detection of multi-photodetectors by means of intensity fluctuation correlation. We have proven that the intensity fluctuation correlation of thermal light is the result of a randomly grouped subfields (photons) interfering with the group itself.  We have also successfully introduced and studied a measurement protocol to measure the Photon Number Fluctuation Correlation (PNFC), the photon number fluctuation correlation is proportional to the intensity fluctuation correlation.

Realizing multi-photon interference, we have successfully produced two-photon Bell states and three-photon GHZ states as well as two-photon and three-photon qubits from the measurement of photon number fluctuation correlation of randomly grouped photons in thermal state. Utilizing our lower-cost entangled photon pair, we have successfully demonstrated two experiments that probe the foundations of quantum theory: (1) an experimental demonstration of a random delayed choice quantum eraser with randomly paired photons in thermal state which was then compared to our earlier published random delayed choice quantum eraser with an entangled biphoton of SPDC; (2) an experimental demonstration of Popper’s experiment with randomly paired photons in a thermal state which was then compared to our earlier published Popper’s experiment with an entangled biphoton of SPDC. Also, applying our new lower-cost technology, we have successfully simulated a Controlled-NOT gate that is useful for quantum computing.

This project concludes, by utilizing our new lower-cost technology, in principle, it is possible to entangle many randomly grouped photons of thermal light and to produce an n-qubit with n>>2.

Modified by: Yanhua Shih
